conversation.content: The bill is forty-seven [quickly] eighty-three. What's twenty percent?
Jesus Christ, you serious? Move the decimal, double it—nine-fifty-six. Any third-grader with half a brain cell could figure that out without making it a whole production.
Nine fifty-six? That's, um, way too much for chicken that tasted like, you know, cardboard.
Cardboard? You ordered the safest thing on the menu because you're terrified of flavor. Sarah didn't judge your boring-ass palate, so pay the woman her twenty percent.
She forgot my salad, er, entirely until I had to, like, wave her down twice!

Oh boo-fucking-hoo, she forgot your, hmm, three leaves of iceberg lettuce. Meanwhile she's juggling twelve tables because, actually, management fired half the staff last week—I mean, cut her some slack.
Fifteen percent then? That's, well, about seven dollars which seems, you know, more reasonable for the, uh, actual service we got?
Seven dollars? Are you, like, fucking kidding me right now? She spent two hours pretending your stupid jokes were funny—honestly, that alone deserves hazard pay, so, twenty percent minimum.
Fine! But I'm not, err, tipping on the wine that was already, basically, marked up three hundred percent.
The wine you insisted on ordering to impress your date who left after the appetizer? Yeah, you tip on that humiliation tax too, buddy.
Twenty-three dollars for house wine is [delighted] highway robbery!

Highway robbery is you thinking, umm, anyone gives a shit about your, actually, cheap-ass complaints when Sarah's trying to pay rent on two-thirteen an hour plus whatever scraps people like you leave.
What if we just leave ten bucks?
Ten bucks works—congratulations, you just spent five minutes bitching your way to exactly what I said in the first place. Real smooth negotiation skills there, champ.
Wait... you just, like, rounded up the bill! It's forty-seven dollars, so, er, ten is actually more than twenty percent!
No shit, Sherlock—servers tip out on total sales including, well, tax, which means they're paying the busboy and bartender whether you, honestly, tip properly or not, so yeah, we round up.
This is [passionately] why I hate, you know, going out with you—everything becomes this, um, whole moral crusade!
Moral crusade? I'm just, basically, trying to make sure our server can, hmm, afford groceries while you're crying over two extra dollars like it's your kidney.
Fine! Ten dollars—but, actually, you're paying for parking since you're so, well, goddamn generous with my money.
Your money? You still owe me forty from last week's bar tab, but sure—I'll cover parking while you, err, pretend you're not the cheapest bastard I know, honestly.
